Eli Lilly and Company (Lilly), a global research-based pharmaceutical corporation, is dedicated to delivering innovative pharmaceutical-based healthcare solutions that enable people to live longer, healthier and more active lives.  Lilly is the parent company of Lilly del Caribe, Inc., which has a facility in Guayama, Puerto Rico.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Lilly del Caribe-Guayama has designed and implemented, including:



1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies

2.  Stationary source and regulated substances handled

3.  General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

4.  Five-year accident history

5.  Emergency response program

6.  Planned changes to improve safety





1.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:



Lilly del Caribe is committed to operating and maintaining all processes in a safe and responsible manner.  This is especially important for those processes using hazardous substances.  Lilly del Caribe has numerous systems in place to manage these chemicals.  Lilly del Caribe uses a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to ensure the safety of employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  Lilly del Caribe accidental release prevention programs and contingency planning efforts help effectively manage the hazards that are posed to employees, the public, and the environment by the use of these chemicals.

2.  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:



Lilly del Caribe-Guayama produces a variety of pharmaceutical products using a variety of chemicals and processing operations.   The following regulated substances are handled at Lilly del Caribe-Guayama in quantities above the threshold quantities established under the RMP regulations. 



TOXICS: Hydrogen chloride (anhydrous) [Hydrochloric acid]



FLAMMABLES: None





3.  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:



Lilly del Caribe-Guayama is subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management requirements, as well as other OSHA requirements.  The facility is also subject to regulation by other agencies, including the Puerto Rico Environmental Quality Board and the United States Environmental Protection Agency.



Specific prevention programs include conducting pre-startup and design hazard assessments, proactive maintenance programs, routine vessel inspections, emergency response training, safe to work programs, employee and contractor safety programs, and accident investigation programs.



Lilly has been a part of the American Chemistry Councils Responsible Care® initiative since its inception in 1989.  Responsible Care began in 1989 as a collection of management practices that are organized around Codes of Management Practice.  The original code consisted of Community Awareness and Emergency Response and was complemented by five other codes by the end of 1992.  Those five codes are Distribution Safety, Employee Health and Safety, Pollution Prevention, Process Safety and Product Stewardship.  At Lilly, our st

rategy has been to integrate the management practices associated with these 6 codes into our health, safety and environmental management policy and principles as well as our global policy requirements.  Continuous improvement has been driven by annual self-evaluation of the codes.



A new Responsible Care was rolled out by the American Chemistry Council in 2001, which responds to both public feedback about the initiative and the changing global economic and socio-political climate.  The new Responsible Care initiative has resulted in a Responsible Care Management System (RCMS) technical specification, which all member companies must implement and then seek external certification to verify implementation.  Furthermore, an additional Code of Management Practice was added to address chemical security.  As required by the Responsible Care initiative, all affected sites have completed security vulnerability assessments.  As a result of these assessments, action plans were developed to address critical items identified.  



Lilly takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:



1. Process safety information

2. Process hazard analysis

3. Operating procedures

4. Training

5. Mechanical integrity

6. Management of change

7. Pre-startup review

8. Compliance audits

9. Incident investigation

10. Employee participation

11. Hot work permit

12. Contractors



These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.





4.  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:



Lilly del Caribe-Guayama has had no accidents as defined in 40 CFR 68

.42 during the past five years. 



5.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:



EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AT LILLY DEL CARIBE-GUAYAMA 

The Lilly del Caribe ? Guayama emergency response is coordinated by plant security and EHS Department using the plant's emergency response teams and equipment.  The emergency response plan spells out the "hows" of emergency response and the roles and responsibilities of the incident response and management response teams.  Regular drills test readiness and help employees practice responses to alarms and incidents.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE TEAMS

Lilly del Caribe ? Guayama has an internal Emergency Brigade.  Site emergency response teams undergo regular training to meet local, state, federal and company requirements.  The emergency response organization has responsibility for response equipment.  Vehicles on site include a fire truck, HAZMAT truck, an ambulance and a vacuum truck.  The site also has an on-site medical facility.





6.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:



Lilly del Caribe ? Guayama is committed to ongoing safety improvement.  Accident prevention is incorporated into each stage of the facility's life cycle, from the up-front design and construction through start-up, operation and maintenance to any facility expansion or modification.  The multiple safeguards ensure accident prevention.  Ongoing safety improvements include safely designing, building, or modifying facilities. Employees and contractors are appropriately trained and tested.  Equipment is safely started or re-started following pre-startup safety reviews.  The plant is safely operated using detailed operating procedures that include safe operating limits.  Equipment is regularly inspected and maintained.  Process hazard reviews are completed and periodically updated.  The entire safety system is regularly audited.
